instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
Board no liquid damage, seem very clean, tried good hard drive flex cable and hard drive with os x installed good know 

hard drive turn,  and screen with "?"

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_HDD_FLT</SIGNAL> 5v present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U4510</CHIP> area.
Post some of its voltages and signals.

J4501 also needs <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> present <CHIP>U4510</CHIP> area look good 

noticed odd not working also

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PP5V_SW_ODD</SIGNAL>?
Also measure <SIGNAL>SMC_ODD_DETECT</SIGNAL> w/ and w/o ODD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SW_ODD</SIGNAL> 5V present

i've not now odd, i need just hard drive recognized

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
Yeah, ODD test can help to detect the issue...
HDD and ODD issues at same time point to PCH, if both powers are OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message: exactly i will get new one odd for test ;)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
so <SIGNAL>SMC_ODD_DETECT</SIGNAL> 0.056V when odd plugged,

if unplug odd i've 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No hdd detected
threads.message:
Yeah, but is ODD detected by OSX?
If not, that should be PCH issue for both HDD and ODD not detected.
